Comment: > Isn’t that what’s already happening in a practical sense with taxes applied to gasoline? EVs are not subject to that tax that funds the roads, despite also providing wear and tear.   Yes, but again see my notes on why I do not find it fair. Here's an explanation:   * Car A, ICE, 25 years old, weighs 3000 pounds, gets 25 mpg * Car B, ICE, brand new, weighs 3000 pounds, gets 35 mpg * Car C, Hybrid, brand new, weighs 3000 pounds, gets 45 mpg * Car D, EV, brand new, weighs 3000 pounds, no gas.   If each of those cars go 10,000 miles in a year (and lets say it's all equal driving as well, same exact mix of city and highway), what's a fair amount they should pay in "gas" taxes?   In Ohio:  * Car A pays $154.00 * Car B pays $110.00 * Car C pays $185.56 * Car D pays $200.00  (10K miles / mpg * Ohio's $0.385 per gallon gas tax, + hybrids have a $100 registration fee, EVs have a $200 registration fee).   I believe they should all pay the same since they all put equal wear and tear on the roads. But car A is punished for being less efficient (and this will impact the poor more since they don't buy newer/more expensive vehicles). Cars C and D are punished for being electric.   Now let's say they drive a lot, 30,000 miles a year:  * Car A pays $462.00 * Car B pays $330.00 * Car C pays $356.67  * Car D pays $200.00  Now car A is REALLY punished, B and C aren't too bad, but still unfair for C, and D is loving it.

Comment: The conventional wisdom that commercial trucks are destroying streets and highways has been around for a long time but how true is that really. I know that anecdotal evidence doesn’t carry any weight but these two make me have my doubts. When I was a kid growing up in Queens, we used the Belt Parkway a lot from the area of JFK to the Verrazano Bridge. Nearly every trip along that route also involved driving the NJ Turnpike from Elizabeth @ Exit 13 to the Delaware Memorial Bridge and further down I-95. Throughout the 1960’s and 70’s, the Belt was a potholed mess. Like something out of a war zone. Coupled with it being constructed through swampland, and the road having rises and dips, it was a roller coaster ride. Note that as a NYC parkway, there was no commercial traffic allowed. The lane width, grades, bridge clearances and ramps simply are not and still are not up to it. Contrast that with the NJ Turnpike which at six lanes in each direction carries all north-south traffic along the eastern seaboard. Three of those lanes are separated and designated for trucks. And the road was always smooth. I believe this is due to it being properly designed, constructed and maintained for its use. Today, the Northern State Parkway on Long Island, which is also limited to passenger vehicles, develops into a potholed mess every few years, seeing repaving only ahead of election years.
